genMap

public int[] genMap(int seed,
                    int maxHeight)
genMap has the simple purpose of turning the noise into a map of solids and non-solids. There are two for loops. The first one goes through and lowers anything above the height limit. The second loop fills in anything underneath the noise, to make it a solid platform.

Parameters:
seed -
maxHeight -
Returns:

smooth

public void smooth(int[] map,
                   int denom)
This method "smooths" an array of numbers dividing the numbers into groups, and then going through each group with the following process: 1. Find the median of the group. (median1) 2. Find the median of each number within that group, with median1. 3. Go to the next group. The purpose of dividing the numbers into groups is to preserve occasional unique structures.

Parameters:
map -
denom - (denominator) can now be manually set, which allows for custom smoothness.

genBlocks

public int[] genBlocks(int[] map)
genBlocks takes a map made up of solids and non-solids (1s and 0s), and gives it life. The first step is to check whether or not it is a solid. If it's not a solid, then by default, it must be sky. The second step, assuming that it is not a solid, is to determine what level of depth the block is on. At dirt-level, it will check to see if the block above is sky, and if so, this dirt will have grass. At rock-level, there is a chance that dirt may cascade down. There is also a rare chance that ores may appear! In this instance, diamond has been implemented. At bedrock-level, it is a barrier that cannot be moved. 0=sky 1=grass 2=dirt 3=stone 4=diamond 5=bedrock

Parameters:
map -
Returns:

genNoise

public int[] genNoise(int length)
This is where the magic happens! In this little method, it will take a noise generation sequence and fit it into a 1d block-like world. Currently it is using a custom sin(x) value, which I would like to replace with Perlin noise once I can understand it.

Parameters:
length -
Returns:

smoothNoise

public void smoothNoise(int[] map,
                        int blend,
                        int smoothness,
                        int detail)
smoothNoise simply takes advantage of the possibilities of using the smooth method. By having multiple variables, the map can be very unique and still look smooth, instead of being all uniform.

Parameters:
map -
blend -
smoothness -
detail -
